<xsl:apply-imports>

As well as <xsl:next-match>, <xsl:apply-imports> can be used to invoke an overridden template rule. It only considers template rules in imported stylesheet modules.

Reference

  • <xsl:with-param>

<xsl:choose>

There are two instructions in XSLT that support conditional processing: <xsl:if> and <xsl:choose>. <xsl:choose> provides selection of one choice when there are several possibilities. It consists of a sequence of one or more <xsl:when> elements, followed by an optional <xsl:otherwise> element. Each <xsl:when> element has a single attribute, test which specifies an expression. When <xsl:choose> is processed, each of the <xsl:when> element is tested in turn until one of them is satisfied. Only the content of the first <xsl:when> that is satisfied is evaluated. If none is satisfied, the <xsl:otherwise> is considered.

Reference

  • <xsl:when>
  • <xsl:otherwise>

<xsl:for-each>

<xsl:for-each> instruction processes each item in a sequence of item, evaluating the sequence constructor for each item.

the select attribute is required, and the expression must evaluate to a sequence. If there is an <xsl:sort> element present, the input sequence is sorted.

<xsl:if>

There are two instructions in XSLT that support conditional processing: <xsl:if> and <xsl:choose>. <xsl:if> provides simple if-then conditionality. It has a mandatory test attribute which specifies an expression.

<xsl:next-match>

As well as <xsl:apply-imports>, <xsl:next-match> can be used to invoke an overridden template rule. It considers template rules of lower import precedence or priority.

An <xsl:fallback> instruction appearing as a child of <xsl:next-match> is ignored by an XSLT-2.0 processor, but can be used to define fallback behavior when the stylesheet is processed by an XSLT-1.0 processor in forwards-compatible mode.

Reference

  • <xsl:with-param>
  • <xsl:fallback>

  • ordinal avt
  • grouping-separator avt
  • grouping-size avt

<xsl:otherwise>

In a <xsl:choose> instruction, when none of the <xsl:when> element is satisfied, the optional <xsl:otherwise> is considered, and processed.

Reference

<xsl:param>

The <xsl:param> element may be used as a child of <xsl:stylesheet>, <xsl:template>, or <xsl:function> to define a parameter to the transformation. Such a paramater can be set by the caller: by the xslt processor, when the <xsl:stylesheet> is invoked, by the <xsl:call-template>, <xsl:apply-templates>, <xsl:apply-imports>, <xsl:next-match>, when a <xsl:template> is invoked, or as a child of <xsl:function> to define a parameter to a stylesheet function, which may be supplied when the function is called from an XPath expression.

The name of the is defined by the name attribute, and its default value is supplied by the caller. If no value was supplied by the caller, then it is define by the expression of the select attribute. The optional as attribute defines the required type of variable. If specified, the value of the variable is converted to the required type using the function conversion rules. For <xsl:stylesheet> and <xsl:template> parameters, the optional required attribute may be used to indicate that the parameter is mandatory. It must not be specified for <xsl:function> parameter which are alwasy mandatory.

The value of the parameter named "name" can be accessed with the "$name" expression.

<xsl:variable> and <xsl:parameter> can be used to create temporary trees and two-phase transformations.

Reference

  • name QName
  • select expression
  • as sequence-type
  • required yes-or-no
  • tunnel yes-or-no

  • <xsl:apply-imports>

<xsl:stylesheet>

Reference

<xsl:template>

<xsl:template> defines the processing that can be be applied to node that match a particular pattern. It contains a sequence constructor for creating nodes and/or atomic values. If it has a match attribute, it is invoked when an <xsl:apply-templates> selects a node that match the pattern specified in the match attribute. If it has a nameattribute, it is invoked explicitely by name.

A <xsl:template> must have either a match attribute or a name attribute. If it has no match attribute, it must have no mode attribute and no priority attribute. If present, the as attribute the result of the sequence constructor is converted to the specified type (or raise a type error if it is not possible.

Reference

  • match pattern
  • priority xs:decimal
  • mode modes
  • name QName
  • as sequence-type

<xsl:variable>

The <xsl:variable> element declares a variable which may be global or local. It has a required name attribute which specifies the name of the variable. The value of the variable is defined either by the expression of the select attribute or the sequence constructor. If the <xsl:variable> has a select attribute, the sequence constructor must be empty. The optional as attribute defines the required type of variable. If specified, the value of the variable is converted to the required type using the function conversion rules.

The value of the variable named "name" can be accessed with the "$name" expression.

<xsl:variable> and <xsl:parameter> can be used to create temporary trees and two-phase transformations.

Reference

  • name QName
  • select expression
  • as sequence-type
  • <xsl:analyze-string>
  • <xsl:apply-imports>
  • <xsl:apply-templates>
  • <xsl:attribute>
  • <xsl:call-template>
  • <xsl:choose>

  • <xsl:copy-of>

  • <xsl:for-each-group>
  • <xsl:if>

<xsl:when>

Specifies, with the test attribute, an expression to be tested as part of an <xsl:choose> instruction.

Types

QName

A QName. This schema does not use the built-in type xs:QName, but rather defines its own QName type. Although xs:QName would define the correct validation on these attributes, a schema processor would expand unprefixed QNames incorrectly when constructing the PSVI, because (as defined in XML Schema errata) an unprefixed xs:QName is assumed to be in the default namespace, which is not the correct assumption for XSLT. The data type is defined as a restriction of the built-in type Name, restricted so that it can only contain one colon which must not be the first or last character.

Reference

QNames

A list of QNames. Used in the [xsl:]use-attribute-sets attribute of various elements, and in the cdata-section-elements attribute of xsl:output

Reference

avt

This type is used for all attributes that allow an attribute value template. The general rules for the syntax of attribute value templates, and the specific rules for each such attribute, are described in the XSLT 2.0 Recommendation.

Reference

char

A string containing exactly one character.

Reference

expression

An XPath 2.0 expression.

Reference

input-type-annotations-type

Describes how type annotations in source documents are handled.

Reference

level

The level attribute of xsl:number: one of single, multiple, or any.

Reference

method

The method attribute of xsl:output: Either one of the recognized names "xml", "xhtml", "html", "text", or a QName that must include a prefix.

Reference

mode

The mode attribute of xsl:apply-templates: either a QName, or #current, or #default.

Reference

modes

The mode attribute of xsl:template: either a list, each member being either a QName or #default; or the value #all

Reference

nametests

A list of NameTests, as defined in the XPath 2.0 Recommendation. Each NameTest is either a QName, or "*", or "prefix:*", or "*:localname"

Reference

pattern

A match pattern as defined in the XSLT 2.0 Recommendation. The syntax for patterns is a restricted form of the syntax for XPath 2.0 expressions.

Reference

prefix-list

prefix-list-or-all

prefix-or-default

Either a namespace prefix, or #default. Used in the xsl:namespace-alias element.

Reference

prefixes

sequence-type

The description of a data type, conforming to the SequenceType production defined in the XPath 2.0 Recommendation

Reference

uri-list

validation-strip-or-preserve

Describes different ways of type-annotating an element or attribute.

Reference

validation-type

Describes different ways of type-annotating an element or attribute.

Reference

yes-or-no

One of the values "yes" or "no".

Reference

yes-or-no-or-omit

One of the values "yes" or "no" or "omit".

Reference
